A New Regime • • •
To aid the student body in the forthcoming elections, we are
printing below, excerpts from the Student Council constitution
dealing with the purpose of the Council and the duties of the
Council president. We think it is immediately evident that this
document badly needs revision and clarification. The question the
students should consider is how this revision should be carried out,
and how the duties of the president should be strengthened.
The four main objects of the Council as stated in the present
Council constitution are as follows:
"(a) To serve as intermediary between Administration, faculty, students, and undergraduate activities.
"(b) To correlate the various University activities, promoting
cooperation of all parties in matters affecting the welfare of the
University.
"(c) To uphold and promote the Johns Hopkins Honor System.
"(d) To speak for the student body in dealings with parties
outside of the University as provided in Article VI, Sections 4
and 5."
According to the present Council by-laws, the Student Council
president shall:
"1. Carry out in spirit and detail the provision of the Constitution and by-laws.
"2. Preside at meetings of the Student Council.
"3. Preside at student assemblies when necessary.
"4. Keep in close touch with the faculty, students and student
affairs.
"5. Organize the Freshman class.
"6. Oversee the enforcement of the Freshman regulations,
if any have been passed.
"7. Direct /arrangements for, and hold inter-class contests.
"8. Supervise class election.
"9. Co-operate with the authorities in the preservation of the
proper conduct of students and of the good appearance of the buildings, grounds, lunch-rooms, etc.
v10. Perform any additional duties which may arise consistent
with the four main objects of the Student Council."
Of the four main purposes of the Council constitution listed
above, (a) and (b) are blanket clauses in need of concrete definition. Parts of (a) and (b) and all of (c) are duties now fulfilled by
other campus groups. Articlg VI Section 4 of (d) refers to the
honor Code. Section 5 of that Article is a further blanket clause
in need of definition. It reads:
"The Student Council shall have the power to speak for the
student body in dealings with parties outside the University on
questions of concern to the entire student body. If necessary, the
Student Council shall refer questions that may be the outcome of
such dealings to the student body for decision by vote."
This needs clarification. As it stands it tends to give the impression that the Council and the student body presume upon
themselves the powers of the University administration.
Of the President's duties, one, four, nine and ten are blanket
clauses and semi to require interpretation and clarification by the
Council president himself six and seven are duties now performed
by other campus organizations. Two and three are simple chairing
duties. Five and eight thus are the only provisions that seem to
ential any major duties, if "major duties" they can be called.
The Council president's duty to organize politically the freshman
class and supervise class elections is a heavy responsibility and we
are not trying to minimize the fact. But how strong and active is
the Council today? Constitutionally, can the president do more
than just run a series of popularity polls?
The man who leads a revision of the constitution must be a
person who has insight into the campus, who has the tact to help
organizations, and who has the imagination to see problems and
their solutions.
If, by nature of some extraordinary miracle, the student body
in the April 20-21 election chooSes a president on more stable
grounds than popularity appeal and/or social affiliation, we hope
he will be mature enough, of a character strong enough, and objective enough to disregard friendship ties and personal feelings
in order to appoint the m‘st responsible and best qualified men
on 'campus to his committees.
We hope he will vigorously clarify, define, re-define and perhaps even spur the Council to recast its constitution.
Finally, we hope he will be the long awaited Council president:
the Council president who will shake the Council out of its cumbersome dormancy and make it a meaningful organ of student
representation and campus government.

Homewood, Baltimore, April 9 1954

A New Regime • • •
To aid the student body in the forthcoming elections, we are
printing below, excerpts from the Student Council constitution
dealing with the purpose of the Council and the duties of the
Council president. We think it is immediately evident that this
document badly needs revision and clarification. The question the
students should consider is how this revision should be carried out,
and how the duties of the president should be strengthened.
The four main objects of the Council as stated in the present
Council constitution are as follows:
"(a) To serve as intermediary between Administration, faculty, students, and undergraduate activities.
"(b) To correlate the various University activities, promoting
cooperation of all parties in matters affecting the welfare of the
University.
"(c) To uphold and promote the Johns Hopkins Honor System.
"(d) To speak for the student body in dealings with parties
outside of the University as provided in Article VI, Sections 4
and 5."
According to the present Council by-laws, the Student Council
president shall:
"1. Carry out in spirit and detail the provision of the Constitution and by-laws.
"2. Preside at meetings of the Student Council.
"3. Preside at student assemblies when necessary.
"4. Keep in close touch with the faculty, students and student
affairs.
"5. Organize the Freshman class.
"6. Oversee the enforcement of the Freshman regulations,
if any have been passed.
"7. Direct /arrangements for, and hold inter-class contests.
"8. Supervise class election.
"9. Co-operate with the authorities in the preservation of the
proper conduct of students and of the good appearance of the buildings, grounds, lunch-rooms, etc.
v10. Perform any additional duties which may arise consistent
with the four main objects of the Student Council."
Of the four main purposes of the Council constitution listed
above, (a) and (b) are blanket clauses in need of concrete definition. Parts of (a) and (b) and all of (c) are duties now fulfilled by
other campus groups. Articlg VI Section 4 of (d) refers to the
honor Code. Section 5 of that Article is a further blanket clause
in need of definition. It reads:
"The Student Council shall have the power to speak for the
student body in dealings with parties outside the University on
questions of concern to the entire student body. If necessary, the
Student Council shall refer questions that may be the outcome of
such dealings to the student body for decision by vote."
This needs clarification. As it stands it tends to give the impression that the Council and the student body presume upon
themselves the powers of the University administration.
Of the President's duties, one, four, nine and ten are blanket
clauses and semi to require interpretation and clarification by the
Council president himself six and seven are duties now performed
by other campus organizations. Two and three are simple chairing
duties. Five and eight thus are the only provisions that seem to
ential any major duties, if "major duties" they can be called.
The Council president's duty to organize politically the freshman
class and supervise class elections is a heavy responsibility and we
are not trying to minimize the fact. But how strong and active is
the Council today? Constitutionally, can the president do more
than just run a series of popularity polls?
The man who leads a revision of the constitution must be a
person who has insight into the campus, who has the tact to help
organizations, and who has the imagination to see problems and
their solutions.
If, by nature of some extraordinary miracle, the student body
in the April 20-21 election chooSes a president on more stable
grounds than popularity appeal and/or social affiliation, we hope
he will be mature enough, of a character strong enough, and objective enough to disregard friendship ties and personal feelings
in order to appoint the m‘st responsible and best qualified men
on 'campus to his committees.
We hope he will vigorously clarify, define, re-define and perhaps even spur the Council to recast its constitution.
Finally, we hope he will be the long awaited Council president:
the Council president who will shake the Council out of its cumbersome dormancy and make it a meaningful organ of student
representation and campus government.
